case_name: K. S. Srinivasan v. Director General, All India Radio

facts.text: Shri K. S. Srinivasan was appointed to a post of Liaison Officer, All India Radio, on May 1, 1946, on a pay of Rs. 350 per month.

anchor.surface_text: On May 1, 1946, Shri K. S. Srinivasan, appellant before us, was appointed to a post of Liaison Officer, All India Radio, on a pay of Rs. 350 per month in the scale of Rs. 350-20-450-25/2-550.

facts.text: The posts of Liaison Officers were permanent and pensionable but filled on a temporary basis.

anchor.surface_text: It was stated in the said memorandum that the posts were permanent and pensionable, but would be filled on a temporary basis the memorandum further stated that if the persons companycerned were retained in service and companyfirmed in the posts, they would be allowed pensionary benefits

facts.text: Designation Liaison Officer was later changed to Public Relations Officer.

anchor.surface_text: The designation Liaison Officer was later changed to Public Relations Officer, and along with other posts of Listener Research Officer and Assistant Station Director, the posts of Public Relations Officers were upgraded to Rs. 450-25-500-30-800 with effect from January 1, 1947.

facts.text: Posts of Public Relations Officers upgraded to Rs. 450-25-500-30-800 with effect from January 1, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The designation Liaison Officer was later changed to Public Relations Officer, and along with other posts of Listener Research Officer and Assistant Station Director, the posts of Public Relations Officers were upgraded to Rs. 450-25-500-30-800 with effect from January 1, 1947.

facts.text: On May 23, 1952, Director General, All India Radio, appointed appellant to Public Relations Officer grade in quasi-permanent capacity from May 1, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: On May 23, 1952, the Director General, All India Radio, passed an order bearing 1298 No. 2 1 A/50 in which it was stated that whereas the appellant had been in companytinuous Government service for more than three years and a declaration had been issued to him in pursuance of rr. 3 and 4 of the Central Civil Services  Temporary Service  Rules, 1949

facts.text: On September 3, 1952, appellant received order that services not required after October 6, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: On September 3, 1952, however, the appellant received an order from the said Director-General in which it was stated that his services would number be required after October 6, 1952.

facts.text: Appellant made representation on September 8, 1952, claiming right to alternative post.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was naturally taken by surprise on receipt of this order and made a representation on September 8, 1952, in which he stated that as a quasi-permanent Public Relations Officer he had a claim to an alternative post in the same grade

facts.text: On September 13, 1952, appellant appointed to officiate as Assistant Station Director, Madras, in temporary capacity.

anchor.surface_text: On September 13, 1952, the appellant was informed by means of an order that he was appointed to officiate as Assistant Station Director, Madras  the appellant was then working as Public Relations Officer, All India Radio, Madras  in a purely temporary capacity until further orders.

facts.text: Appellant appeared before Union Public Service Commission on March 26, 1953, for Assistant Station Director posts.

anchor.surface_text: While Government was companysidering the representation of the appellant, the Union Public Service Commission interviewed in March, 1953, candidates for the posts of Assistant Station Directors. The appellant appeared before the Commission on March 26, 1953.

facts.text: On April 18, 1953, appellant informed not selected by UPSC.

anchor.surface_text: On April 18, 1953, the appellant was informed that the Union Public Service Commission had number selected him and the appellant was again informed that it was number possible to companytinue him in service.

facts.text: On July 3, 1953, memorandum stated posts of PRO form separate cadre from ASD.

anchor.surface_text: On July 3, 1953, the appellant received a memorandum dated June 9, 1953. This memorandum said Shri Srinivasans representation has number been companysidered by Government. As the posts of Public Relations Officers form a cadre by themselves and do number belong to the cadre of Assistant Station Directors

facts.text: On December 14, 1953, order stated appellant carries quasi-permanent status of PRO to ASD post.

anchor.surface_text: No. 41 R  Government of India, Director General, All India Radio. No. 1  113 -SI/52. New Delhi, the 14th December, 1953. ORDER. In this Directorate Order No. 2 1 -A/50, dated the 23rd May, 1952, Shri K. S. Srinivasan, then officiating 1301 Public Relations Officer, All India Radio, was appointed to that post in a quasi-permanent capacity with effect from the 1st May, 1949.

facts.text: On August 31, 1955, appellant informed UPSC objected to his ASD appointment.

anchor.surface_text: On August 31, 1955, the appellant was informed by the then, Secretary, Miniistry of Information and Broadcasting, that the Union Public Service Commission had objected to his appointment as Assistant Station Director

facts.text: On September 7, 1955, order required appellant to relinquish ASD post and offered temporary Assistant Information Officer.

anchor.surface_text: On September 7, 1955, the appellant received the final order 1302 of Government, which is the order companyplained of in the present appeal. That order was in these terms Shri Srinivasan was declared quasi-permanent in the grade of Public Relations Officer

facts.text: On October 11, 1955, order transferred appellant to Press Information Bureau as officiating Assistant Information Officer.

anchor.surface_text: and on October 11, 1955, an order was passed transferring the appellant to the Press Information Bureau as officiating Assistant Information Officer with immediate effect and the appellant was directed to hand over charge of the post of Assistant Station Director immediately

facts.text: On November 25, 1955, Punjab High Court summarily dismissed Writ Petition 209-D of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: On November 25, 1955, the appellant filed a petition, numbered Writ Petition 209-D of 1955 in the Punjab High Court in which he prayed for the issue of a writ of certiorari or any other appropriate writ for quashing the orders dated September 7, 1955, and October 11, 1955, and asked for an order directing his reinstatement

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment dated November 25, 1955, of Punjab High Court in Civil Writ No. 209-D of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 25, 1955, of the Punjab High Court in Civil Writ No. 209-D of 1955. 1297 S. Krishnaswamy Aiyanger and C. V. L. Narayan, for the appellant.

facts.text: Special leave obtained on April 23, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon, the appellant moved this Court for Special Leave and obtained such leave on April 23, 1956.

facts.text: In 1952, all posts of Public Relations Officers except one in External Services Division held in abeyance.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently, in August 1952, all posts of Public Relations Officers, except the one in the External Services Division, were held in abeyance.

facts.text: Posts of PRO and ASD not in same cadre or grade.

anchor.surface_text: we have reluctantly but ineluctably companye to the companyclusion that the post of Assistant Station 1313 Director is number in the same grade or cadre as the posts of Public Relations Officers.

facts.text: Appellant held quasi-permanent status in grade of Public Relations Officers.

anchor.surface_text: Now, it is beyond dispute and in fact, admitted that the appellant held a quasi-permanent status in the grade of posts known as Public Relations Officers.

facts.text: Punjab High Court dismissed certificate application on March 16, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: That application was also dismissed on March 16, 1956.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on February 18, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: 1958. February 18. The Judgment of Das C. J., Venkatarama Aiyar, S. K. Das and Sarkar, JJ., was delivered by S. K. Das Bose J. delivered a separate judgment.

facts.text: Appeal and petition dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: BY COURT The appeal and the petition are dismissed.

facts.text: Appellant filed petition under Art. 32 on April 22, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: On April 22, 1956, the appellant also filed a petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution

facts.text: In 1952, only surviving PRO post assigned to permanent incumbent.

anchor.surface_text: the only post that survived the economy drive was assigned to the permanent incumbent.

facts.text: Appellant handed over charge under protest on October 19, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant refused to accept the lower post of Assistant Press Information Officer and on October 19, 1955, he made over charge under protest.

facts.text: UPSC concurrence obtained for quasi-permanent appointment on May 23, 1952 order.

issues.text: The main question for decision in the appeal is whether the impugned orders violate the constitutional guarantee given by Art. 311(2) to the appellant, who is admittedly the holder of a civil post under the Union.

holdings.text: The impugned orders do not violate the constitutional guarantee given by Art. 311(2).

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, we hold that there has been no violation of the constitutional guarantee under Art. 311(2) in the case of the appellant. The appeal must, therefore, be dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant had no right to the post of Assistant Station Director; termination not punishment under Art. 311 as no forfeiture of right.

holdings.text: The appellant had no right to the post of Assistant Station Director.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the critical question is-did the appellant have a right to the post of Assistant Station Director, which he was holding, when the impugned orders were passed ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reduction certified; ASD not same grade/cadre so no proviso protection; termination valid under rule.

holdings.text: No estoppel arises out of the order dated December 14, 1953.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant not misled; mistake on grade similarity; admission not conclusive.

holdings.text: The impugned orders do not violate Arts. 14 and 16.

anchor.surface_text: As to the petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution, we do not think that there has been any such discrimination against the appellant as is contemplated by Arts. 14 and 16 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No discrimination; non-selection by UPSC not breach; others properly selected.

holdings.text: The appeal and the petition are dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: BY COURT The appeal and the petition are dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No merits found; no violation of rights.

holdings.text: The order dated December 14, 1953 clearly and unequivocally makes him quasi-permanent in the new post. (Dissent)
holdings.reasoning_summary: Objective construction of public order; carries quasi-permanent status to new post.
Following precedent on Art.320(3); no injustice if directory.

precedents.citation: Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union Of India 1

anchor.surface_text: The true scope and effect of Art. 311 of the Constitution was fully companysidered in a recent judgment of this Court in Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union Of India  1 , pronounced on November 1, 1957, and it was there held by the majority as follows   we are quoting such observations only as have a bearing on the present case  Shortly put, the principle is that when a servant has a right to a post or to a rank either under the terms of the companytract of employment, express or implied, or under the rules governing the companyditions of his service, the termination of the service of such a servant or his reduction to a lower post is by itself and prima facie a punishment,

precedents.case_name: Parshotam Lal Dhingra v Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: Scope and effect of Art. 311(2): termination of service is punishment if servant has right to post; otherwise not
precedents.cited_holding: If the servant has no right to the post... the termination of his employment does not deprive him of any right and cannot, therefore, by itself, be a punishment.

precedents.citation: State of U. P. v. Manbodhan Lal Srivastava 1

anchor.surface_text: In State of U. P. v. Manbodhan Lal Srivastava  1  it has been held that the provisions of Art. 320 3  c  of the Constitution, as respects companysultation of the Public Service Commission on all disciplinary matters affecting a person serving the Government of India or a State Government, are not mandatory in spite of the use of the word I shall therein.

precedents.case_name: State of UP v Manbodhan Lal Srivastava
precedents.cited_proposition: Provisions of Art. 320(3)(c) requiring consultation with Public Service Commission are not mandatory
precedents.cited_holding: Art. 320(3)(c) is not mandatory; advice of Commission not binding on Government

precedents.citation: The Commissioner of Police, Bombay v., Gordhandas Bhan i 1

anchor.surface_text: I had occasion to observer while delivering the judgment of the Court in The Commissioner of Police, Bombay v., Gordhandas Bhan i  1 , that- Public orders, publicly made, in exercise of a statutory authority cannot be construed in the light of explanations subsequently given by the officer making the order of what he meant, or of what was in his mind, or what he intended to do  and I add in this case, what he subsequently discovered  .

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Police Bombay v Gordhandas Bhanji
precedents.cited_proposition: Public orders made by public authorities must be construed objectively based on language used, not subsequent explanations
precedents.cited_holding: Public orders, publicly made... cannot be construed in the light of explanations subsequently given by the officer making the order

precedents.citation: State of U. P. v. Manbodhan Lal Srivastava 1

anchor.surface_text: But so, I would have thought at first blush, do the words in Art. 320 3  of the Constitution. They are equally emphatic. They are equally imperative. But this Court held in the State of U. P. v. Manbodhan Lal Srivastava  1 , after a careful examination of the whole position, that they do not mean what they seem to say and that they are directive only and not mandatory.

precedents.case_name: State of UP v Manbodhan Lal Srivastava
precedents.cited_proposition: Words in Art. 320(3) are directive only and not mandatory

precedents.citation: Biswanath Khemka v. The King Emperor 2

anchor.surface_text: The Federal Court construed a similar provision.in s. 256 of the Government of India Act, 1935, in the same way  Biswanath Khemka v. The King Emperor   2  and so did the Privy Council in a Canadian case in Montreal

precedents.cited_proposition: Similar provision in s.256 Government of India Act 1935 construed as directory

precedents.citation: Montreal Street Railway Company v. Normandin 1

anchor.surface_text: and so did the Privy Council in a Canadian case in Montreal Street Railway Company v. Normandin  1 . Their Lordships said at page, 175 that when a statute prescribes a formality for the performance of a public duty, the formality is to be regarded as directory only if to hold it as mandatory would cause serious general inconvenience or injustice.

precedents.case_name: Montreal Street Railway Company v Normandin
precedents.cited_proposition: Statutory formalities for public duties are directory if mandatory would cause inconvenience or injustice
precedents.cited_holding: when a statute prescribes a formality... the formality is to be regarded as directory only if to hold it as mandatory would cause serious general inconvenience or injustice
